data.citation: Alexandre Blanchet (French, 1882–1961). Two Friends, 1912. Oil on canvas; 157.5 × 111.8 cm (62 1/2 × 44 in). Fondation Gottfried Keller, Musee d’art et d’histoire, Geneva.

data.title: Pasturage, 1912
data.medium: Oil on canvas; 73.3 x 91.4 cm (28 7/8 x 36 in)
data.description: A successful painter and later a celebrated printmaker, Segonzac was not affiliated with any major art movement of the early twentieth century. His wide range of aesthetic inspirations can be seen in Pasturage, from the pastoral landscapes of the Barbizon school to the bright palette of the avant-garde Fauves. After corresponding with Walt Kuhn, executive secretary for the Association of American Painters and Sculptors, Segonzac sent five works to the Chicago presentation of the Armory Show. Two paintings, including Pasturage, were purchased by Arthur Jerome Eddy, who would write in Cubists and Post-Impressionism about the artist’s independent view.
data.citation: André Dunoyer de Segonzac (French, 1884–1974). Pasturage, 1912. Oil on canvas; 73.3 × 91.4 cm (28 7/8 × 36 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Arthur Jerome Eddy Memorial Collection, 1931.516.

data.ctitle: 91 Maurice Denis, Nausicaa (Lent by M. E. Druet)

Constantin Brâncusi (French, born Romania, 1876–1957). Mlle. Pogany, 1912. Plaster; sculpture: 45.5 × 23.4 × 23.4 cm (17 7/8 × 9 3/16 × 9 3/16 in.); base: 17.5 × 19 cm (6 7/8 x 7 1/2 in.). Musée National de l’Art Moderne, Paris, bequest of Constantin Brâncusi, 1957, AM 4002-50.
Wilhelm Lehmbruck (German, 1881–1919). Kneeling Woman, 1911. Cast stone; 175.8 × 138.4 × 69.8 cm (69 1/4 × 54 1/2 × 27 1/2 in.) Albright-Knox Art Gallery, Buffalo. Charles Clifton Fund, 1938:12.
